Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 3.30 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 40 on food and USD 80 on other expenses. V. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase chickens and rice to resell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy chickens and rice.

loans.name: Jenelyn

Her husband Alejandro, who is 50 years old, works as a fish vendor to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have nine children who are between 8 and 27 years old. Jenelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jenelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her seventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000 to use as funds for her business operations so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and family. Jenelyn is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

Rosita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to use as additional capital for her business so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. loans.name: Korn

texts.en:
Korn S., 53, resides with his family in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. S. and his wife are farmers and grow vegetables, earning an income of $7 per day. Each month, the family has to spend $56 on food and $28 on the other necessary expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase cows to raise for sale. In the future, he would like to use the additional income to repair his house. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy cows to raise for sale

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok Y., a sixty-eight year-old resident of Kompong Tom Province, possesses a plot of farmland upon which she grows rice. She is married to Mr. Ou Ken, age 72, who also earns his living as a local farmer. They are blessed with four children, one of whom is a blacksmith worker, another a sewing worker, while the other two are married.

Sok is concerned because one of her sons has encountered some financial problems in his business. She is therefore requesting a loan to purchase iron for her son to weld in his window construction and sales business.

loans.use: To purchase iron for her son's business

loans.name: Clara

texts.en:
Clara P. is from the village of Brgy. Bagahabag, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 51 years old, married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Clara owns a general store where she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste to the local community. Clara has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2011, Clara joined ASKI to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clara is requesting her first loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use any additional revenue generated from her business to improve the living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste for resale

Vilma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Vilma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to purchase a stock of raw materials so that she can continue to save up for her children's future education and family needs. Vilma is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

Ouy C. will use this loan of U.S. $700 to buy a new motorbike for her husband, whose existing motorcycle is old and unreliable.  In the photo that accompanies this profile, Ouy C. is pictured with her husband at their home.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en:
Khiev P. is a widowed farmer who lives with two children in the Takeo province. She works raising animals and growing rice, typically making US $1.70 per day. She is also supported by two children working in a garment factory. 

Khiev P. wants to take out a loan of US $500 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.name: Cleto

texts.en:
Cleto Y. is from the village of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 24 years old. Cleto is single. 

To make a living, Cleto owns and operates a jeepney (small bus) transport service. Cleto has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Cleto joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Cleto is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair his vehicle for better service. This will be the first loan taken out by Cleto from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Adelaida's Group

texts.en:
Adelaida M. is from the village of Sandiat West. She is 57 years old. Adelaida is the group leader of a 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Adelaida M..

Adelaida is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Adelaida owns and operates a tailoring business. Adelaida has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Adelaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Adelaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 38,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as cloth, needles and threads. 

Adelaida is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be the 12th loan taken out by Adelaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Jerry's Group

texts.en:
Jerry T. is from the village of San Bonifacio. He is 36 years old. Jerry is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Jerry T..

Jerry is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jerry raises livestock, primarily pigs, for sale. Jerry has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Jerry joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Jerry is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Jerry from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Loem

texts.en: Loem C. is 23 years old and married.  She has been earning income selling clams in and around Kompong Tom province.  She typically generates a profit about $2.50 a day to help support her family. In order to increase her income, Loem C. is requesting a loan to purchase some feed and piglets to raise to sell when they are big enough.

loans.use: To purchase feed and piglets to raise for sale

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen C., 54, resides with her family in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantation. 

C. is a farmer, earning an income of US $1 per day. Her husband is a village chief, earning an income of US $0.50 per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $60 on food and US $6 on the other necessary expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of US $500 for motorbike spare parts to resell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy motorbike spare parts to resell

loans.name: Manuela's Group

texts.en:
Manuela R. is from the village of Sto. Domingo. She is 45 years old. Manuela is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Manuela R..

Manuela is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Manuela plants and harvests a variety of vegetables for sale. Manuela has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Manuela joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and  living situation. Manuela has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. 

Manuela is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Manuela from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Chem

texts.en:
Chem K., 43, resides with her family in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. 

K. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of US $3 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $41 on food and US $8 on the other necessary expenses. 

K. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase groceries to sell. By doing so, she will be able to start a new business and generate more income. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy groceries to resell

loans.name: Mean

texts.en:
Mean S. resides with her family in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. 

S. sells groceries for an income of US $4 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of US $5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $41 on food and US $ 4 on the other necessary expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of US $1,200 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. By doing so, she will be able to generate more income. 

In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

In the photograph,  S. and her husband are selling sugarcane juice.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Eoun

texts.en:
Eoun C. resides with her family in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. 

C. and her husband are farmers and sell rice, earning an income of US $3 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $37 on food and US $7 on the other necessary expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of US $600 to purchase horses to transport rice and other products to sell. By doing so, she will be able to generate more income. 

In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy horses to transport rice and other products to sell

loans.name: Nut

texts.en: Nut P. has been in the farming business with her husband since 2005. They have a plot of farmland which comes from their grandparents. In addition, Nut P. sells many products in her community, Kompong Cham province. The items which she always sells are meat, vegetables, fresh fish, and cooking ingredients. This couple typically generates an income of $5 each day to manage their family and especially to meet the hunger of their two children. However, the family recently is facing difficulty with their living conditions due to their house needing repair. To solve the problem, Nut P. would like a loan to buy some planks to repair a part of her broken house. Nut P. and her husband appear in the photo.

loans.use: To buy some planks to repair a part of her broken house

loans.name: Dienalyn's Group

texts.en:
Dienalyn C. is from the village of Sto. Domingo. She is 34 years old. Dienalyn is the leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Dienalyn C..

Dienalyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she plants and harvests  a variety of vegetables for sale. Dienalyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Dienalyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Dienalyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Dienalyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Sen S. resides with her family in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Sen and her husband are farmers, earning an income of USD 0.6 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 7 on other necessary expenses. 

Sen is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase two cows to help plow the rice field, a measure that will allow her to generate more income. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy two cows to help plow the rice field

loans.name: Battulga

texts.en:
Battulga, 28, is married and lives with his wife and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia, residing in a two-room house in his father's backyard on the outskirts of the city. Two of their children attend a local primary school.

Battulga began making Mongolian traditional boots in 2006, assisted by his wife while taking care of the children at home. They manufactured the footwear by hand until they bought a sewing machine for 365,000 MNT in 2010, a purchase that has made their job much easier. The boots they now produce are both traditional and modern styles which are bought by both Mongolians and foreign visitors. Battulga and his wife currently have one employee who earns a salary of 150,000 MNT per month.

Their business has expanded little by little and will continue to grow. Battulga is a hardworking person and caring father who says, "We have our sewing machine and we need to have our own workshop in the future." He is requesting a loan of 700,000 MNT to buy leather and other necessary materials for his boot-making business.

loans.use: To buy leather and other necessary materials

loans.name: Purevhuu

texts.en:
Purevhuu, 29, is married and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in his father-in-law's backyard. His wife is unemployed and takes care of their two little children. 

He began transporting coal in 2007. He transports coal from a mine that is located close to Ulaanbaatar and sells it at a local market. In the summer he transports goods for various businesses. He wants to work for mining companies in the future as a driver. He is a hardworking and modest person who says, " I want to make more money and buy an apartment in the future". 

He is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to buy spare parts for his truck.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his truck

loans.name: Dunchinsuren

texts.en:
Dunchinsuren, 49, is married and lives with his wife and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they own on the outskirts of the city. They have a decent standard of living due to the transportation service business he started in 2000. He transports people from one side of the city to the other. Now his business has become more stable and his daily net income is around $64. 

He is an open-minded and hardworking person who says, "I am trying to make more money and build a house where we can have a comfortable life." He is requesting a loan of 1,800,000 MNT to buy spare parts and pay maintenance fees for his microbus.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Naranchimeg

texts.en:
Naranchimeg, 35, is married and lives with her husband and two sons in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her husband works as a driver for a company, and one of her two sons attends a local school. 

She began selling clothes in 2008. She imports consumer goods from China, and her sister who lives in Russia helps her sell the clothing there. She is a hardworking and honest person who says, "I want my two children to get a good education and buy an apartment so they can have a comfortable life." 

Naranchimeg is requesting a loan of 500,000 MNT to use for purchasing more clothes from China to sell in Russia.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes from China

loans.name: Gantulga

texts.en:
Gantulga is 47 years old and lives with his son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They moved there in 2001 from Suhbaatar province. His son is currently studying at college. 

Gantulga began transporting goods with his truck between Ulaanbaatar and the eastern provinces of Mongolia in 2001. In addition to that he brings sand that is used for construction and sells it at a local market that specializes in construction material. A full truck of sand sells at between 100,000-110,000 MNT. 

He is a hardworking and polite person who says, "I would like to buy a new car for my son." He is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to buy spare parts and tires for his truck.

loans.use: To buy spare parts and tires for his truck

loans.name: Morng

texts.en: Morng S., age 31, owns a small kiosk where she sells meat, shampoo, soft drinks and food in her village in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She typically makes around 5 USD in profit each day to ensure that her family has a comfortable life. She has a life partner in her husband who is a car taxi driver at the local factory. He has an income about 5 USD each day and shares responsibility with Morng S. to support the whole family. She now has two school-aged kids, both of whom attend school. She will use her first loan to buy a tractor for her husband to dig land. This loan is going to improve the whole family with additional assets, and earning more profit.

loans.use: To buy a tractor

loans.name: Edna's Group

texts.en:
Edna C. is from the village of Santo Domingo. She is 51 years old and the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Edna C..

Edna is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. She raises pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $138 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Edna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. 

Edna is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 8th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Divina is a 28-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and a farming business. She lives in Quezon, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2009 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,400. Divina is borrowing PHP 13,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Divina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at  http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Rowena's Group

texts.en:
Rowena A. is from the village of Rang-Ay, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 31 years old. Rowena is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Rowena is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $58 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Rowena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Baktykan's Group

texts.en:
Baktykan A. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Uzgen, a nice, ancient town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 49 and unfortunately she is a widow. She has raised five children: three daughters and two sons. The daughters are married and the sons are working in Russia. In order to earn money to meet her personal needs Baktykan breeds livestock and cultivates agricultural products. She started this activity three years ago with the initial investment of 10,000 KGS. Now she earns 5,000 KGS per month. With money received from the loan, she plans to purchase mineral fertilizers for farming. In the future she wants to improve the family’s living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Virginia's Group

texts.en:
Virginia D. is from the village of Calaocan, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 39 years old and the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. Virginia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling detergent and bar soaps. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $70 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Virginia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Virginia is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Sugarjav

texts.en:
Mr.Sugarjav is 31 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Dornod Aimag, Kherlen Soum, in the  far eastern province of Mongolia, which is 500 miles away from the capital city. Since 2004, Mr. Sugarjav has been running a transport business. He carries people from the center of Dornod Aimag to different remote "soums" (towns).  He has gained a lot of experience during the last 6 years and he has a good reputation among his colleagues and customers.

His wife works as a teacher in secondary school. The family keep a few cows for milking purposes. They sell surplus milk to neighbors to earn some extra money.  This time Mr. Sugarjav is planning to buy more cows to increase the family income. The loan will be used to buy cows to increase their income from selling milk.

loans.use: to buy a few cows and animal feed to increase his income from selling milk

loans.name: Elvira's Group

texts.en:

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Elvira is married and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $206 a month for these activities.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is a 35-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and a cafeteria. She lives in Mabinay, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and cafeteria businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000. Mary Ann is borrowing PHP 27,000 to purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Mary Ann aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

texts.ru: Атахонов Бозор проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 56 лет. Женат. Имеет 7 детей. Образование - высшее, экономист. По профессии проработал 10 лет. На сегодняшний день он занимается животноводством. Разводит крупнорогатый скот в дальнейшем для продажи. В этой области уже четыре года. Кредит просит для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Bozor A. lives in the Yavan district.  He is 56 years old, married and has 7 children.  He has a higher education, as an economist.  He spent 10 years working in that profession.  Today, he is involved in animal husbandry.  He breeds cattle for future sale.  Bozor has been in this business for four years.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle.

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa is a married woman who lives in Mabinay, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a tailoring/sewing business. Her husband Benjamin, who is 55 years old and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have nine children who are between 14 and 32 years old. Felisa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Felisa has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to use as funds for her business operations so that she can continue to save up for her children's education. Felisa is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Sok Y., age 31, who lives in the Province of Kompong, Chhnang province in Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs. Sok Y. has run this business since 1999 and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living. She was married, but she divorced her husband back when her kids were still young. She has one child who is good at making baskets, and she always sells her finished products to people who come to order directly at her house. 

In order to earn extra income, Sok Y. will be using the loan to buy more pig feed and piglets to raise for sale.

loans.use: To buy more pig feed and piglets to raise for sale

loans.name: Emelie

texts.en:
Emelie is a 44-year-old separated woman who supports her family by operating a piggery and a food processing business. She lives in EB Magalona, Negros Occidental. Emelie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Emelie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 50,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 30,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 50,000 to use as additional funds for her business operations so that she can continue to save up for the future and to hire other people for her business and provide income for them. Emelie is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: To fund her business operations

loans.name: Nansalmaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Nansalmaa is 45 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They do not have their own plot of land and currently they live in a 'ger', the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, on Nansalmaa’s sister’s plot of land. 

Nansalmaa sells underwear and lingerie at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar city. Once or twice a month she travels to Ereen, a Chinese border city, and buys her products from wholesalers. She is planning to buy a car to use for transportation of her products. Every morning she has to carry her products to the market and in the evening she carries them back home, because she rents a stall in the market and there is nowhere to store her products. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy a small car to carry her products to the market.

loans.use: to buy a small car to carry her products to the market

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

She has operated a fish selling business for the past four years, selling wholesale to her neighbours and passersby. Fatuma faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase a freezer for storing fish for sale. She decided to work with Yehu because of its good reputation in society.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer for storing fish for sale

loans.name: Chenee

texts.en:
Chenee is a married woman who lives in the municipality of Dalaguete, Cebu. She earns her living by operating fish vending and fishing businesses. Her husband Ralph, who is 32 years old, works as a vendor to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are between 3 and 12 years old. Chenee joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Chenee has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 22,400, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500 to use as additional capital for her fish vending business so that she can continue to save up for the education of her children. Chenee is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: To fund the operation of her business

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a 40-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a food vending business and a general store. She lives in EB Magalona, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1996 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 20,000. Judith is borrowing PHP 25,000 to purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 21st loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Judith aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
From Kompong Chhnang province, Sun S. is a 37-year-old married woman who is good at making bamboo baskets at home. Her husband always helps her by taking the finished products to sell in and around his community. They also buy baskets from other weavers at a reasonable price and resell them to gain extra profit. They have done this since 1980. 

Sun S. is a mother who has four single children. Recently, Sun S. has taken out a loan to invest in her business by purchasing more baskets for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more baskets to sell, together with her own

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

She has been operating a firewood selling business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition, she also sells charcoal, which contributes to her income. Mwanasiti faces a major challenge in the high cost of transporting charcoal in her business. She hopes to become a wholesale supplier of firewood in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase a bundle of firewood for resale. She decided to work with Yehu because of its good reputation in the community.

loans.use: To purchase firewood to sell

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is a married woman who lives in the municipality of Rizal, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two businesses:  food vending and rice retailing. Her husband Rey, who is 54 years old, works as an Ice Plant Operator to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are between 10 and 31 years old. Vilma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Vilma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th loan, she is borrowing PHP 16,000 to fund the operation of her food vending business so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Vilma is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.use: To fund the operation of her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve and expand his business by increasing working capital

loans.name: Heidy

texts.en:
Heidy is a 45-year old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  a sari-sari (general) store and farming.  She lives in the municipality of Quezon, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. Heidy is borrowing PHP 15,000 to purchase more stock to sell.  This will be her eighth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Heidy aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional inventory

loans.name: Esther Sidi

texts.en:
Esther Sidi N. is a 48-year-old lady. She is married to David and they have one child.

Esther has been a charcoal vendor for the last two years. She has never borrowed from any other MFI, and this is her first loan from KADET LTD.  With this loan, she plans to purchase sacks of charcoal to sell. The anticipated profits will be directed into the expansion of her business.

Her dream is to expand her business and own a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal to sell

loans.name: Lourdes' Group

texts.en:
Lourdes R. is the group leader of a 5-member group loan arranged by ASKI. While each member of the group would receive an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if, say, one member is delinquent or defaults on his or her portion of the group loan.

Lourdes is a 51-year-old woman from the village of Carabatan Punta, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is married and has 5 adult-age children. To earn a living, Lourdes owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector. Specifically, her primary source of income is derived from planting and harvesting coconut for sale. Lourdes has been engaged in her business for over 9 years, and she earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2010, Lourdes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. In turn, she hopes to be better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her family's standard of living. Lourdes is requesting a loan in the amount of 7,000 PHP (of the 33,000 PHP, or $775, group loan being sought), which would be used to purchase additional inventory and to increase her working capital. This loan would be the first loan taken out by Lourdes from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to supplement her family's income.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen/women, and entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional inventory and increasing working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase maize flour, rice, soda, beans and sugar to resell

loans.name: Luon

texts.en:
Luon R. is 58 years old.  She is the mother of seven children –  four of whom are single, and three are married and now live in their own houses. 

To make a living, Luon R. grows rice crops on her farmland, which has belonged to her since 1979.  On average, she can earn a profit of approximately $1 each day.  Luon R. has a life partner in her husband who is a recycling seller.  He earns an income about $2 each day.  He buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells them in bulk to other countries.  

Luon R. is looking for a loan to buy used goods to sell, and to buy a used motorcycle to transport them to the buyers.

loans.use: To purchase used goods to sell & a motorcycle for transport

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard M. is 26 years old.  He is from Pap Onditi, married to Lucia, and they have one child who is two years old.

Bernard has a retail shop that he has been running for the past four years.  He is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a friend who is a client here.  

Bernard wants to buy soap, cooking oil, baking flour, etc. to add to his stock.   He is very optimistic that his business will do well after the loan investment.   He earns a monthly income of KES. 12,000.

His dream is to be able to have more stock than what he has today.

loans.use: Buy soap, cooking oil, baking flour to sell

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia is a widow who lives in EB Magalona, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a fishing/fish vending business. She has six children who are between 20 and 43 years old. Lilia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lilia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000 to pay for repairs of her pump boat and purchase another pump boat so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Lilia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: To repair her pump boat and purchase another pump boat.

loans.name: Dioleta

texts.en:
Dioleta is a 48-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a ready-to-wear clothes/pants business and a fish vending business. She lives in the municipality of Sta. Fe, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000. Dioleta is borrowing PHP 29,500 to purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Dioleta aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. loans.use: To purchase more clothes, shoes and pants for resale

loans.name: Mary Grace's Group

texts.en:
Mary Grace V. is from the village of Nampicuan. She is 33 years old. Mary Grace is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Mary Grace V.".

Mary Grace is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Mary Grace owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Mary Grace has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Mary Grace joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Grace has successfully repaid a previous loan of 32,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in renovating the business. Mary Grace is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Mary Grace from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic is a married woman who lives in the municipality of Sta. Fe, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a ready-to-wear clothes/pants business. Her husband Evante, who is 33 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who are between 4 and 9 years old. Marivic joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marivic has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to buy more stock so that she can continue to save up for the future higher education of her children. Marivic is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.
